problem.tex: Suppose that the radius of convergence of \[f(z)=\sum_{n=0}^\infty a_nz^n\] is R. Prove the power series \[\sum_{n=0}^\infty\frac{1}{n+1}a_nz^{n+1}\] has the same radius of convergence $R$, and is actually the derivative of $f$.

solution.tex: Recall the radius of convergence $R$ is given by the root test, \[\frac{1}{R}=\limsup_{n\to\infty}\sqrt[n]{a_n}.\] To show the new radius is the same, we have to show \[\limsup_{n\to\infty}\sqrt[n]{a_n}=\limsup_{n\to\infty}\sqrt[n]{\frac{a_n}{n+1}}.\] However, we know $\limsup\sqrt[n]{a_n}=\frac{1}{R}$. Then all we have to show is that $\limsup\sqrt[n]{n+1}=1$. This is easy enough, \[\lim\sqrt[n]{n+1}=\lim e^{\frac{\ln(n+1)}{n}}=\exp\left(\lim\frac{\ln(n+1)}{n}\right)=\exp\left(\lim\frac{\frac{1}{n+1}}{1}\right)=e^0=1.\] So we have shown that the radius of convergence is the same. Moreover, let $S_n$ be the $n^{th}$ partial sum for $f$. The derivative of $S_n$ is the $n+1^{th}$ partial sum of the series in question, call it $S'_n$. Because our convergence is uniform (on compact sets), we can swap limits around. Then \[f'(z_0)=\lim_{z\to z_0}\frac{f(z)-f(z_0)}{z-z_0}=\lim_{z\to z_0}\lim_{n\to\infty}\frac{S_n(z)-S_n(z_0)}{z-z_0}=\lim_{n\to\infty}\lim_{z\to z_0}\frac{S_n(z)-S_n(z_0)}{z-z_0}=\lim_{n\to\infty}S'_n(z_0).\]
